page.title: Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Intransitive and Copular Sentences
page.introduction: Simple intransitives do not have any complements after the verb. Motion verbs include a location in the form of either a PP or adverb. English examples include:

EnglishExample.exItem: My mother went to the store.

form.instruction: Partial subcategorization can be done as follows, without entering a feature on every verb: if a particular verb is intransitive and can never have anything but a subject, mark it with the feature intransitive. (Don't consider temporal elements.) If it is an intransitive motion verb that can have a locative PP or AdvP following preceding it, add the feature motion to its lexical entry.
form.introduction: Copular sentences can have an adjective, PP, or nominal phrase following the copular verb. Some languages do not require a copular verb or auxiliary to be present. English examples include:
form.instruction: Add the feature copular to the verbs that take AdjP, PP or predicate nominative complements. Since the motion and copular verbs are a small, closed set, these features must be entered in the lexicon on the appropriate verbs; the default setting is -motion and -copular.

radioGroup.prompt: Do copular type sentences require an overt verb in your language?
radioGroup.radio: No, neither a verb nor an auxiliary is required
No, but an auxiliary is required

radioGroup.prompt: Is there an affix which occurs on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective in copular sentences?

form.instruction: Add either of the features copular_prefix or copular_suffix as appropriate in the lexicon.
